value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Thus the life of a reader is bound</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">up in the life of the book. <add hand="typewriter" place="above">a xxxx constantly merging</add> is to some extent the life of <add hand="typewriter" place="above">the book.</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was to satisfy this unshaled blind infant,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>s retching</sic>
              <corr>stretching</corr>
            </choice> out his hands and covering his eyes in the Eliza</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">bethan playhouse that the 
            <choice>
              <sic>oew</sic>
              <corr>owe</corr>
            </choice> the Elizabethans novels.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or that very curious book <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-trav" key="Unfortunate Traveller, The">The Unfortunate 
            <choice>
              <sic>Travller</sic>
              <corr>Traveller</corr>
            </choice></rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a half born book; a book that is still amorphous</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>neother</sic>
              <corr>neither</corr>
            </choice> one thing nor the 
            <choice>
              <sic>othet</sic>
              <corr>other</corr>
            </choice>; a book that cannot walk;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and yet now and then like an 
            <choice>
              <sic>unwildy</sic>
              <corr>unwieldy</corr>
            </choice> child gambols and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">breaks the 
            <choice>
              <sic>ornmanets</sic>
              <corr>ornaments</corr>
            </choice>. But while <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William">
              <choice>
                <sic>Sahkepeare</sic>
                <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
              </choice></rs> lived,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the novel was always turning into the play. The reader</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was too weak to make his influence felt.</l>
